bibl.title: Letter from Henry P. Birmingham to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 2, 1925

div1.p: Birmingham believes that Gorgas withdrew his request for retirement because of World War I, not because there was opposition to his retirement from other sources.

div1.head: Letter from Henry P. Birmingham to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 2, 1925
div1.opener:
THE HOSPITAL
UNITED STATES SOLDIERS' HOME
WASHINGTON, D. C.
February
Second,
1 9 2 5.
Colonel J. R. Kean, U.S.A., Retired
Army Medical Museum & Library,
7th and B Sts, S. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
In reply to your inquiry concerning General Gorgas,
I would say that the only reason I ever heard for the
withdrawal of his request for retirement was the breaking
off of our diplomatic relations with Germany, which of
course at the time was merely a preliminary to the declar-
ation of war. If there was opposition for any other reason
anywhere, I never heard of it, and if there was such opposi-
tion it was quite likely, under the circumstances, that it
would have come to my attention in some way.

The time of the request for retirement was shortly
before the break in our relations with Germany.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, H. P. Birmingham
Colonel, U. S. Army,
Retired.
